etymologies: Middle English: from Old French soupe ‘sop, broth (poured on slices of bread)’, from late Latin suppa, of Germanic origin

definitions: a liquid dish, typically made by boiling meat, fish, or vegetables, etc., in stock or water
shortDefinitions: liquid dish made by boiling meat or vegetables in stock

definitions: a substance or mixture perceived to resemble soup in appearance or consistency

examples.text: the waves and the water beyond have become a thick brown soup

shortDefinitions: substance or mixture regarded as resembling soup in appearance or consistency

definitions: the chemicals in which film is developed.
shortDefinitions: chemicals in which film is developed

definitions: nitroglycerine or gelignite, especially as used for safecracking.
increase the power and efficiency of an engine or other machine

examples.text: souping up an engine's power can increase pollutants

shortDefinitions: increase power and efficiency of engine

definitions: make something more elaborate or impressive

examples.text: we had to soup up the show for the new venue

shortDefinitions: make something more elaborate or impressive
